sections.name: Zero-runtime
sections.content: Stylesheets-in-TypeScript.  Write your styles in TypeScript (or JavaScript) with locally scoped class names and CSS Variables, then generate static CSS files at build time.  Basically, itâ€™s â€œCSS Modules-in-TypeScriptâ€ but with scoped CSS Variables + heaps more.  > ðŸš§   Please note, this is an alpha release.  ðŸ”¥   All styles generated at build time â€” just like Sass, Less, etc.  âœ¨   Minimal abstraction over standard CSS.  ðŸ¦„   Works with any front-end framework â€” or even without one.  ðŸŒ³   Locally scoped class names â€” just like CSS Modules.  ðŸš€   Locally scoped CSS Variables, @keyframes and @font-face rules.  ðŸŽ¨   High-level theme system with support for simultaneous themes. No globals!  ðŸ›    Utils for generating variable-based calc expressions.  ðŸ’ª   Type-safe styles via CSSType.  ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸   Optional runtime version for development and testing.  ðŸ™ˆ   Optional API for dynamic runtime theming.  ---  Write your styles in .css.ts files.

sections.name: Requirements
sections.content: Your project must be using webpack with the supplied webpack plugin, but that's it.

sections.name: Thanks
sections.content: Nathan Nam Tran for creating css-in-js-loader, which served as the initial starting point for treat, the precursor to this library. - Stitches for getting us excited about CSS-Variables-in-JS. - SEEK for giving us the space to do interesting work.

sections.name: Setup
sections.content: There are currently a few integrations to choose from.

sections.name: Webpack
sections.content: Install the dependencies.

sections.name: esbuild
sections.content: Install the dependencies.   > Please note: There are currently no automatic readable class names during development. However, you can still manually provide a debug ID as the last argument to functions that generate scoped styles, e.g. export const className = style({ ... }, 'className');

sections.name: Gatsby
sections.content: To add to your Gatsby site, use the gatsby-plugin-vanilla-extract plugin.

sections.name: API
sections.content: ðŸ¬ If you're a treat user, check out our migration guide.

sections.name: style
sections.content: Creates styles attached to a locally scoped class name.     > ðŸ’¡ To improve maintainability, each style block can only target a single element. To enforce this, all selectors must target the & character which is a reference to the current element. For example, '&:hover:not(:active)' is considered valid, while '& > a' and `& ${childClass}] are not. >  >If you want to target another scoped class then it should be defined within the style block of that class instead. For example, [& ${childClass}] is invalid since it targets ${childClass}, so it should instead be defined in the style block for childClass. > >If you want to globally target child nodes within the current element (e.g. '& > a'), you should use [globalStyle` instead.

sections.name: globalStyle
sections.content: Creates styles attached to a global selector.

sections.name: mapToStyles
sections.content: Creates an object that maps style names to hashed class names.  > ðŸ’¡ This is useful for mapping to component props, e.g. ``    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createTheme
sections.content: createGlobalTheme  Creates a theme attached to a global selector, but with locally scoped variable names.    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.  ## createTheme

sections.name: createGlobalTheme
sections.content: Creates a theme attached to a global selector, but with locally scoped variable names.    > ðŸ’¡ All theme variants must provide a value for every variable or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createThemeVars
sections.content: Creates a collection of CSS Variables without coupling them to a specific theme variant.  > ðŸ’¡ This is useful if you want to split your themes into different bundles. In this case, your themes would be defined in separate files, but we'll keep this example simple.

sections.name: assignVars
sections.content: Assigns a collection of CSS Variables anywhere within a style block.  > ðŸ’¡ This is useful for creating responsive themes since it can be used within @media blocks.    > ðŸ’¡ All variables passed into this function must be assigned or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: createVar
sections.content: Creates a single CSS Variable.

sections.name: fallbackVar
sections.content: Provides fallback values when consuming variables.

sections.name: fontFace
sections.content: Creates a custom font attached to a locally scoped font name.

sections.name: globalFontFace
sections.content: Creates a globally scoped custom font.

sections.name: keyframes
sections.content: Creates a locally scoped set of keyframes.

sections.name: globalKeyframes
sections.content: Creates a globally scoped set of keyframes.

sections.name: Dynamic API
sections.content: We also provide a lightweight standalone package to support dynamic runtime theming.

sections.name: createInlineTheme
sections.content: Generates a custom theme at runtime as an inline style object.

sections.name: setElementTheme
sections.content: Sets a collection of CSS Variables on an element.    > ðŸ’¡ All variables passed into this function must be assigned or itâ€™s a type error.

sections.name: setElementVar
sections.content: Sets a single var on an element.

sections.name: calc
sections.content: Streamlines the creation of CSS calc expressions.
